text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: junior (1-3 years of experience)

"Hello everyone,
I started working as a freelance content marketer (B2B tech and SaaS niche) in March 2020. Before that, I applied and looked for a full-time job but didn't get any. I don't have extensive knowledge/experience working as a content marketer; I am a total newbie from a developing country. I also finished graduation from maths in January. That's my background, nothing fancy. Whatever, I know I learned from blogs, books and groups.

Until March 2021, it was all going well. I had a few client's (some from Linkedin, some from cold emailing), but one by one, they all stopped working with me. Reason: my writing skills aren't up to par. Now, this is becoming a very stressful situation because I'm not sure what should I do. I know they are many areas that I lag, and I'm trying everything that I can do—like, using Grammarly, getting it to proofread. But nothing is working. Now, I don't have any clients. It's very depressing. I'm trying to land new client's, but nothing is working anymore. What should I do? I was thinking of hiring an editor/mentor who can guide me, especially in my writing part, but I don't have any money. I'm stuck. Please, help me. 
"
Thanks Patrick, I agree with all of this. Much appreciated.

elements.text: Thanks Patrick, I agree with all of this. Much appreciated.

text:
That’s tough! I’m sorry that’s creating stress for you. I have two suggestions that might help!
1. Team up with an editor for every project you land. When you are coming up with the fee for each project include the fee of the editor in your price. That way when the client pays you can pay your editor (disclaimer: I’m not sure if this is a common thing to do. It’s something I’ve considered doing when writing in my second language. But maybe someone else can weigh in on this).
2. You could also consider being very candid in the way you pitch yourself to potential clients. Let them know that you are still developing your writing skills and that they should hire you if they have an in-house editor or a content strategist that can edit your content. And then be sure to also focus on the skills you can offer them: for example your creativity, the fact that you know how to create a well structured blog post and the fact you’re specialized in B2B SaaS content.

elements.text: That’s tough! I’m sorry that’s creating stress for you. I have two suggestions that might help!

Team up with an editor for every project you land. When you are coming up with the fee for each project include the fee of the editor in your price. That way when the client pays you can pay your editor (disclaimer: I’m not sure if this is a common thing to do. It’s something I’ve considered doing when writing in my second language. But maybe someone else can weigh in on this).

You could also consider being very candid in the way you pitch yourself to potential clients. Let them know that you are still developing your writing skills and that they should hire you if they have an in-house editor or a content strategist that can edit your content. And then be sure to also focus on the skills you can offer them: for example your creativity, the fact that you know how to create a well structured blog post and the fact you’re specialized in B2B SaaS content.

text:
I feel like "strategist" is one of most misused role titles out there.

And "specialist" is one of the most useless! (Gripes on these further down)

If you're in a situation where everyone at a certain level is essentially wearing every hat between execution, production, strategy, client service, operations... then you probably have bigger problems than your labels—but I digress.

Rather than untangle that often unavoidable mess, why not go with:

• Junior digital marketer
• Digital marketer
• Senior digital marketer
Base the levels on company seniority, general experience, and current level of responsibility/hats worn

"Digital marketer" is an honest representation of what this mixed bag is.

Strategist means you work primarily on strategy, meaning there's not much execution that you do (read: your hats are few). It's quite senior, generally, because of the fact that you're operating at 30,000 ft and are purposely not in the trenches.

Specialist doesn't mean anything—I feel like it's a word invented by orgs who didn't know how to tackle the nuance of tech/digital and just labeled anyone who seems to know how to work the tweeter as a specialist.

Base the levels on company seniority, general experience, and current level of responsibility/hats worn

"Digital marketer" is an honest representation of what this mixed bag is.

Strategist means you work primarily on strategy, meaning there's not much execution that you do (read: your hats are few). It's quite senior, generally, because of the fact that you're operating at 30,000 ft and are purposely not in the trenches.

Specialist doesn't mean anything—I feel like it's a word invented by orgs who didn't know how to tackle the nuance of tech/digital and just labeled anyone who seems to know how to work the tweeter as a specialist.

text:
If you CAN untangle the mess of hat wearing, label people based on what they spend most of their time doing and what they're responsible for devliering:

• *client service:* happy clients who feel heard
• *project mgmt:* things happen on time, on budget
• *content creation / production:* the authoring of stuff - writing, editing, shooting, drawing, recording, art directing
• *content distribution:* getting the made things out there into the world - publishing, CMS tinkering, PR wrangling, influencer management, spec adjusting
• *operations:* MarTech stuff, making sure the funnels work, getting the site to talk to the chatbot app, salesforce admin stuff
• *creative direction*: feeds into creation/distribution, owning the vision, directing the art directors
• *strategy:* understanding all the links between high level biz objectives, budgets, politics and how they interact or downstream to outputs, KPIs, etc. Making decisions around this, working with creative directors and other senior leaders to move teams in the right direction
• *SEO:* technical + creative analysis stuff that feeds information feedback loops into creation, distro, and ops

text: ^ often most of this stuff and all their subcategories are stuffed into the "strategist/specialist" role :stuck_out_tongue:

text: Hi community! Hope everyone is well. :wave: I wanted to get your thoughts on mentorship. How can one go about finding a mentor? My company is small and so there’s no one really internally that I could go to. Would love to hear your tips and experiences on how you’ve been a mentee/ mentored people in the past, and how that looked like for you. And do you know of any great mentorship programs for women in tech/content? Thanks so much :pray:

elements.text: Hi community! Hope everyone is well.

I wanted to get your thoughts on mentorship. How can one go about finding a mentor? My company is small and so there’s no one really internally that I could go to. Would love to hear your tips and experiences on how you’ve been a mentee/ mentored people in the past, and how that looked like for you. And do you know of any great mentorship programs for women in tech/content? Thanks so much

text: I'm currently involved in the mentoring program through the Content Marketing Institute. Applications are closed for this round of the program, but it may be something to keep on your radar.

elements.text: I'm currently involved in the mentoring program through the Content Marketing Institute. Applications are closed for this round of the program, but it may be something to keep on your radar.

text: I've been peer mentoring more early-career marketers here and there. It's pretty informal -- we'll do a call or two where they ask advice, I make some intros, I send them jobs that are good fits, they send me cover letters. It's more about landing a job than career growth. It just organically happened because I'm passionate about helping early-career people find good work. What are you naturally passionate about/what do you know you need? That's a good place to start! Then you can make more targeted asks. I'd also recommend just reaching out for career advice calls to people in marketing you admire. Flattery will get you everywhere! Even if they can't do monthly career check-ins, you'll leave with new knowledge.

elements.text: I've been peer mentoring more early-career marketers here and there. What are you naturally passionate about/what do you know you need? That's a good place to start! Then you can make more targeted asks. I'd also recommend just reaching out for career advice calls to people in marketing you admire. Flattery will get you everywhere! Even if they can't do monthly career check-ins, you'll leave with new knowledge.

text: Lastly, if your company has continuing education credits or if HR has a learning budget, see if you can have your company hire a coach for you!

elements.text: Lastly, if your company has continuing education credits or if HR has a learning budget, see if you can have your company hire a coach for you!

text: Elpha also matches members to mentors: <https://elpha.com/invite/from-joannarutter>

attachments.title: Elpha: where women build our careers together
attachments.text: Elpha is where women build our careers together. Become a member to connect with peers and mentors, learn from experts, access job opportunities, and make friends. Plus membership is free!

text:
Hi <@U01AHL8AGBB> thank you so much for the insight!! I agree about the made up “specialist” title. :sweat_smile: Are you speaking from an in-house perspective?

Here’s a bit more insight into our organization. I work at a growth marketing agency so for the most part each employee is one of the below roles, which is why we don’t bucket them as “digital marketers.”
• content marketing specialist/strategist
• growth marketing specialist/strategist
• paid acquisition specialist/strategist
How many people we have in each position basically depends on how many clients we have. At the moment we have around 10 people in each bucket/speciality. Then there’s usually a content, growth, and PA person on each client team and every person typically manages around 3 clients at a time. We work with monthly retainers in a monthly sprint model with our clients.

So our organization is pretty flat, since we all have our own clients and provide the same type of services, which is why I’m trying to create a career development path within this. We also haven’t clearly defined what competencies you need to get promoted to a strategist, so I’m working on creating a rubric for performance reviews. And this is where I’m really looking for some ideas. This will help clearly define the developmental path to the next role.

How many people we have in each position basically depends on how many clients we have. At the moment we have around 10 people in each bucket/speciality. We work with monthly retainers in a monthly sprint model with our clients.

So our organization is pretty flat, since we all have our own clients and provide the same type of services, which is why I’m trying to create a career development path within this. We also haven’t clearly defined what competencies you need to get promoted to a strategist, so I’m working on creating a rubric for performance reviews. And this is where I’m really looking for some ideas. This will help clearly define the developmental path to the next role.

text:
My mentor came from this Women in Hi Tech organization. It started as local to Indianapolis, but I believe you can sign up for a mentor and meet remotely if you’re not in the state!
<https://www.womenandhitech.org/Mentoring>

elements.text: My mentor came from this Women in Hi Tech organization. It started as local to Indianapolis, but I believe you can sign up for a mentor and meet remotely if you’re not in the state!

text:
<@U02280S1Q8P> no problem! I'm not in-house these days but my ire about those titles does stem from my time in-house and at an agency

ideas for the rubric:

• *associated conversion success rate(s)* - across all clients or client teams, what's your conversation rate look like? you'll need standardize this in some way since all clients are different. this also helps normalize out differences in revenue, which is a tempting metric but kinda secondary to conversion
• *associated growth rate* - same deal, but tracking whatever counts as growth for the client. prolly revenue, but maybe it's followers for some. Expresses as a % as well so that nice
• *Tenure with organization* - adjust this as you see fit, helps to control outlier situations and give some reward to those with longer tenures
If you're an individual spread across 6.5 teams in this kinda flat, loose structure, I'd think it'd be fair to base those metrics off a selection of maybe your top 5 teams/clients. Or an option to drop the two lowest scores as a way to balance outliers in the negative direction.

Once someone hits an appreciable level in the rubric, they're invited to maybe author a strategy deck or post mortem or something as part of their path to getting that higher rank? The deck is put to the test with a live client, with its own rubric or maybe just the same idea of testing conversion.

text: LOVE these ideas. This is exactly the kind of stuff I’m looking for. Thank you so much <@U01AHL8AGBB>. I didn’t even think about throwing tenure in the mix, probably from some old in-house trauma from previous jobs about lots of people with tenure getting “too comfy” if you know what I mean. But I don’t see this as an issue in our agency as everyone does such fantastic work.

text: I second what <@U016BDEQ40J> says. I know how much of a roller coaster job searching and interviewing can be - and the fact that you have made it this far is great! Just sit back and wait to see what they come back with. You are worth that FT role. :heart:
